description:
Bartonella gabonensis is a gram-negative, facultatively intracellular bacterium that belongs to the genus Bartonella. It was first isolated from the blood of a human patient in Gabon, Africa, and was subsequently named Bartonella gabonensis.

Bartonella gabonensis is a member of the Bartonella genus, which includes several species that are known to cause various diseases in humans and animals. These bacteria are typically transmitted by blood-feeding arthropods, such as fleas, ticks, and lice.

The bacterium is slow-growing and difficult to culture in the laboratory, which has limited the amount of research conducted on its biology and pathogenesis. However, studies have shown that Bartonella gabonensis can infect and replicate within human erythrocytes (red blood cells) and endothelial cells (cells that line blood vessels).

Infections with Bartonella gabonensis have been associated with various clinical manifestations, including fever, lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes), and potentially more severe complications. However, the full range of clinical presentations and the epidemiology of this species are not yet well-characterized due to the limited number of reported cases.

Further research is needed to better understand the ecology, transmission, and clinical significance of Bartonella gabonensis, as well as its potential impact on human and animal health.
